sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying sheet
message_1: A rectangular loop of dimensions $3\text{ cm}\times 5\text{ cm}$ is placed perpendicular to a long straight wire carrying a current of $2\text{ A}$. The loop is centered at a distance of $10\text{ cm}$ from the wire. Calculate the magnetic field at the center of the loop due to the current in the wire.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field at the center of the loop due to the current in the wire, we can use the Biot-Savart law. For a long straight wire, the magnetic field at a distance r from the wire is given by:

B = (μ₀ * I) / (2 * π * r)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A), I is the current in the wire, and r is the distance from the wire to the point where we want to calculate the magnetic field.

In this case, the current I is 2 A, and the distance r is 10 cm (0.1 m). Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

B = (4π × 10⁻⁷ Tm/A * 2 A) / (2 * π * 0.1 m)

The π terms cancel out, and we are left with:

B = (4 × 10⁻⁷ Tm * 2) / (0.1 m)

B = (8 × 10⁻⁷ Tm) / 0.1 m

B = 8 × 10⁻⁶ T

So the magnetic field at the center of the loop due to the current in the wire is 8 × 10⁻⁶ T (8 microteslas).
